person_018.name: DavidHartley
person_018.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of atheism following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_027.name: IsaacMilner
person_027.description: Mathematician and inventor. President of Queens' College, Cambridge, and Lucasian Professor of Mathematics. FRSL.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_086.name: JohnCanton
person_086.description: An experimental natural philosopher and teacher, especially in the field of electricity. FRSL.

person_032.name: FrancisHauksbee
person_032.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_037.name: Sappho
person_037.description: Sappho was an Archaic Greek poet from Eresos or Mytilene on the island of Lesbos. Sappho is known for her lyric poetry, written to be sung while accompanied by music.

place_106.name: Lakes of Killarney
place_106.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

place_014.name: Marazion
place_014.description: Marazion is a civil parish and town, on the shore of Mount's Bay in Cornwall.

place_015.name: St Just in Penwith
place_015.description: St Just, known as St Just in Penwith, is a town and civil parish in the Penwith district of Cornwall.

place_016.name: Mousehole
place_016.description: Mousehole is a village and fishing port in Cornwall.

place_508.name: Land's End
place_508.description: Land's End is a headland on the west coast of Cornwall. It is the most westerly point of mainland England. The underlying rock at Land's End is granite.

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

otherwork_009.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_009.author: William Austin

otherwork_011.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_011.author: Henry Cavendish

otherwork_010.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_010.author: Isaac Milner

otherwork_012.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_012.author: Richard Kirwan

otherwork_017.name: Physical and Chemical Essays: Translated from the Original Latin of Sir Torbern Bergman, 3 vols.
otherwork_017.author: Edmund Cullen (Trans)
